results.title: And You Thought the Platypus Was Odd
results.abstract: “When I first saw it, I just said ‘What?!’ and didn’t speak for a while,” said one of the researchers who studied the fossils of a prehistoric marine reptile.

multimedia.caption: A fossil of Eretmorhipis carrolldongi, a marine reptile with a tiny head and large paddle-like limbs.

results.title: As Climate Warms, Plants Will Absorb Less CO₂, Study Finds
results.abstract: Plants and soil absorb carbon dioxide, which helps mitigate climate change. But global warming will degrade that ability, scientists say.

multimedia.caption: A view from the New York Botanical Garden. Plants absorb greenhouse gases, which helps mitigate climate change.

results.title: During the Lunar Eclipse, Something Slammed Into the Moon
results.abstract: A flash spotted on livestreams was likely caused by the crash of a tiny, fast-moving meteoroid left behind by a comet.

multimedia.caption: A white dot in the bottom left corner of the moon was a flash from a collision with the lunar surface likely caused by a meteorite during this week's lunar eclipse.

results.title: 3 Newborn Endangered Right Whales Seen After Year With No Births
results.abstract: The sighting this winter of newborn whales off the coasts of Florida and Georgia is being greeted with mild optimism, as the North Atlantic population has dwindled.

results.title: Oceans Are Getting Louder, Posing Potential Threats to Marine Life
results.abstract: Increasing ship traffic, sonar and seismic air gun blasts now planned for offshore drilling may be disrupting migration, reproduction and even the chatter of the seas’ creatures.

multimedia.caption: A container ship crossing under the Lions Gate Bridge in Vancouver. Increasing traffic and the threat of seismic blasts for offshore drilling exploration are dangerous to marine life, scientists warn.

results.title: How Ants Sniff Out the Right Path
results.abstract: They may seem like automatons, but ants are surprisingly sophisticated in their navigational strategies.

results.title: Coming Soon to a Police Station Near You: The DNA ‘Magic Box’
results.abstract: With Rapid DNA machines, genetic fingerprinting could become as routine as the old-fashioned kind. But forensic experts see a potential for misuse.

results.abstract: If the Trump administration extends the wall at the southern border, it could degrade important habitats for animals and plants, even birds and insects.

results.title: Douglas Costle, Who Helped Create the E.P.A. and Then Ran It, Dies at 79
results.abstract: He helped conceive the environmental agency that President Nixon created in 1970 and oversaw it through crises in the Carter administration.

multimedia.caption: Douglas M. Costle, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, in 1979 announcing a nationwide effort to identify and seal or remove potentially cancer-causing asbestos in public schools. Almost a decade earlier, Mr. Costlehad helped draw up the blueprints for the agency.

Douglas M. Costle, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, in 1979 announcing a nationwide effort to identify and seal or remove potentially cancer-causing asbestos in public schools. Almost a decade earlier, Mr. Costlehad helped draw up the blueprints for the agency.

results.title: In Davos, Prince William Calls for Action on Mental Health
results.abstract: The second in line to the British throne said his generation should break with the British tradition to keep quiet about emotional struggles.

results.title: Deadly Ebola Virus Is Found in Liberian Bat, Researchers Say
results.abstract: Long a suspected source of the virus, bats had not been confirmed as carriers of the lethal disease in West Africa before. The discovery could help scientists learn more about how the virus infects humans.

results.title: Dark-Sky Tourism: Under the Idaho Sky, a Sense of Belonging
results.abstract: For a transcendant trip, head away from light pollution and crane your neck towards the stars.

results.title: Spinal Fractures Can Be Terribly Painful. A Common Treatment Isn’t Helping.
results.abstract: Injections of bone cement into fractured vertebrae fail to relieve pain any more than a placebo does, researchers found.
org_facet: Journal of Bone and Mineral Research

multimedia.caption: An X ray showing cement injected into a collapsed lumbar vertebra in a 65-year-old patient. Scientists say the procedure, while common, does not effectively relieve pain.

results.title: Mary Boyd Higgins, Wilhelm Reich’s Devoted Trustee, Is Dead at 93
results.abstract: She volunteered for the job with a father of the sexual revolution, even though she had never met him. She protected his legacy and republished his books.

multimedia.caption: Mary Boyd Higgins in 2000 at the Wilhelm Reich Museum in Rangeley, Me. As Dr. Reich’s longtime trustee and the museum’s director, she had rehabilitated the property, originally bought by him in the 1940s.

results.title: How to Stop Rogue Gene-Editing of Human Embryos?
results.abstract: Some U.S. researchers knew of a Chinese scientist’s intentions to implant edited embryos but were unable to stop him. Now scientific institutions are trying to devise global safeguards.

results.title: Scientists Are Teaching the Body to Accept New Organs
results.abstract: Patients receiving new kidneys and livers must take damaging anti-rejection drugs for the rest of their lives. Now researchers hope to train the immune system instead of just tamping it down.

results.abstract: With the Arctic warming rapidly, ice loss in Greenland is accelerating and may soon be a major factor in rising sea levels, according to a new study.

results.title: These Species Were Said to Be Extinct. Really, They Were Just Hard to Find.
results.abstract: A surprising number of plants and animals have been discovered alive and well after scientists had declared them long gone.

results.title: The Elderly and Driving: When Is It Time to Hit the Brakes?
results.abstract: Prince Philip, 97, was involved in a car accident outside London. For families everywhere, the incident raises all-too-familiar questions.

results.title: Your Sweat Will See You Now
results.abstract: A new device — wearable, wireless and battery free — improves the ability to monitor and diagnose health problems by analyzing the sweat on your skin.

multimedia.caption: A soft, wearable patch measures the chemical contents of sweat on the skin. It could be used to screen for cystic fibrosis, and give athletes real-time performance data.
